WRITING.TITLE: A "virtual" learning experience

WRITING.TEXT: Just a few things I can think of off the top of my head: -Website looks like it was made in the early 2000s -"Textbook" is unintuitive and cumbersome -"practice problems" don't show you how to fix errors -Lights buzz and give you headaches -It's essentially all of the individual work of an online course, without the freedom and flexibility (since you're required to do quizzes, labs, and exams AT the math emporium, which is a 30+ minute walk away from some dorms) In general, having a class at the math emporium feels like 30% clicking the back button, 20% confusion, 30% traveling, and 20% learning.
To be fair to the emporium, the help offered there is helpful when you can get it, but the concept of the course baffles me.
got that free parking baby

Facts, I swear I did the problems with excel and a scatter plot over and over and I kept getting the wrong answer. I realized that the right answer was always just a little bit higher than mine, so I just started choosing answers a little bigger than mine. haven't gotten them wrong since.
looks like i'm on the right path then

WRITING.TITLE: All jokes

WRITING.TEXT: My original Meepo Mini's ESC has been really quirky (randomly losing brake power, stutters in acceleration) and it kills me to see this new one :-(
Still have it??
i'm interested in the gullwings
WTB Landyachtz Dinghy

If you're just looking to commute around campus, I would recommend a shorter board (27-30"). I would definitely go with big longboard wheels for the cracks (I ride with 90mm wheels and I still feel my board do a little hop over sidewalk cracks). Some people say they're a little overkill, but my personal favorites are Orangatang Kegels (80a) or if you're getting a smaller board, I love the orangatang in heats (80a). p.s. 80a refers to the "durometer" or the hardness of the wheel. 80a is pretty soft so it'll soften your ride a little and grip to the ground better. p.p.s. some people don't like orangatang (or rather Loaded) because they're products are a little pricier, but I am married to my orangatang kegels and I haven't found wheels that ride quite the same.
huh, the more you know

hate when people shame new riders for this type of thing. really upsets me to know that some potential new riders will feel too shy or uncomfortable to pick up a board. work within your means. if that means a $60 board, ride on. personally, i started on a $20 kryptonics penny board clone from walmart. i think i speak for this whole sub when i say post that baby!! most you'll get is some advice from more experienced riders.

maybe shamed isn't the right word. i just remember learning how to ride, and how i used to practice indoors. maybe i was just an anxious kid, but i really hope other ppl don't have to feel like they having anything to prove to the skate/longboarding community when they're starting out.

WRITING.TEXT: Back in 2006 my parents left the Philippines with only $100 of borrowed money on hand and 6 kids. We had to escape from that economic black hole. My mom had gotten a Visa during the nursing bubble and they had to act quickly as this window would soon close. We arrived in Virginia with no car and no home locked down. Luckily, I was young enough to never feel that struggle, but I am grateful every day for the decision they made to ensure we had enough opportunities to succeed.

WRITING.TITLE: 3 years
WRITING.TEXT: My girlfriend broke up with me after three years. at first i was angry and hurt, but at the end of the day, it was better for her mental health. i don't blame her. it's just so hard not to talk to her and i've caves more than a couple times. she says it's hard for her too, but she seems to be okay with not talking to me. i'm trying to believe she's just stronger, but my anxiety is a bitch :/

im in a difficult spot. essentially, i've deeply hurt my girlfriend. technically, legally, whatever no one was in the wrong. but it happened. i haven't truly contemplated ending it in a while, but now i feel that maybe it would be easier to love someone who hurt you if they were dead. if i died, i just feel like she would be upset, but it would pass because i would no longer be here. no one to love. i just feel so guilty that she still cares about me.
i would kill anyone who hurt her. how do i deal with that?
i appreciate you talking to me today :)

WRITING.TITLE: Beginner here, curious about the pain
WRITING.TEXT: So long story short, I'm wondering if i would be able to handle the pain of a stick and poke. I don't wanna go into it on this sub, but if I can handle a cigarette burn, would I be able to handle the stick and poke pain? Thanks guys! (anyone who cares/is curious enough to investigate, I promise this is for a healthy process related to those issues.)

my plan is to tattoo every 5 tally marks on this progression (a little over half an inch tall, about as wide as a standard sharpie line). how long/how painful do you think this would be? also, would it be valid to stop a tattoo mid way through to finish the next day (new needles and equipment ofc)?

thanks for all your help! :) gonna make sure i order everything i need. is there anywhere (physical store) that sells tattoo needles and ink? i live in VA so i understand if it's only regional or small stores. any ideas?

WRITING.TITLE: Am i going deep enough?
WRITING.TEXT: hey i'm almost too scared to post this, but i really don't know. im a beginner and i started poking my ankle with a needle just to get a feel for it. i've never gotten a tattoo before but i wasn't noticing a pop or really any pain. long story short, just HAD to know if i this depth would actually do anything, so i whipped up a tiny bit of ink and tried it out (note: everything was done with gloves, rubbing alcohol, sterile needles.) still im scared of infection so i really only did a small line with the ink. it looks like the graphite did stay, so i think im going deep enough, but at the same time, i really don't feel any pain from the pokes im doing. do i need to go deeper? is it possible it just doesn't bother me? or is the ankle like a super non-sensitive tattoo area? thanks for the help guys

WRITING.TITLE: first tattoo ever :) just wanted a cute little cactus. not the best, but gotta practice on something #129335; #127997; #8205; #9794; #65039;
Addicted?!?!
WRITING.TEXT: Hey so I did my first stick and poke today and i was really happy about the result, but i reeeeeaaallly wanted to give it another try. anyway, i have three separate tattoos now #128566;. so i mean my semi-serious question is, do i need to calm down? i really like the ones i have and they're all meaningful but i don't wanna doodle all over my body all at once lol. also, i've done one on my ankle, thigh, and top of the hand near the thumb and none of them have really hurt. i'm not sure if i'm just that focused in, but is it possible that i'm not going deep enough? ink is staying in and looks pretty dark but idk, no blood and very very little to no pain.

Damn, I really relate to all that. I feel like Sunday school really turned me off to the whole thing as a kid. Like I agree with most of the values in Catholicism, but I don't like having it force fed to me. Love the vibes dude #128077;
oh thank god you had me worried there for a sec #128514;
thank you!
nice! how do you stop the ink from smudging so much in the fake skin??
i thought the vaseline was just to help stop the skin from tearing! guess this makes a lot of sense too... i wasn't putting vaseline on the fake skin.

so by no means am i an expert, actually im a beginner too, but this is what i got: Pirate face tattoo brand needles (100ct mixed) https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00E3B3OKA/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_awdb_t1_UUHQEb8YEQYV0 Kuro Sumi outlining tattoo ink https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B00424NC4G?psc=1 amp;ref=ppx_pop_mob_b_asin_image# some other things you may want to buy: tattoo transfer paper tattoo transfer gel (both of these are pretty optional) some extra things: kuro sumi also makes other colors and i've only tried their red and black ink, but you may wanna try some of the others. i might get crucified for this, but gloves: if you're tattooing yourself, i don't really think they're necessary; wash your hands and treat your tattoo like a normal wound (but don't put iso on it) and keep the area clean... including your body. oh also, if you're gonna be doing big tattoos or if you cramp up easily like me, invest in some athletic flexible wrap or make a handle for your needles (make sure you sterilize these every time as well!) im a bit of clean freak and my mom's a doctor so i go overkill on infection prevention. just make sure you keep the rubbing alcohol off your tattoos #128534;

oh also green soap is best for pre cleaning and post cleaning i think. https://www.amazon.com/Cosco-Liquid-Stencil-Transfer-Medical/dp/B00DYZ9QVM/ref=mp_s_a_1_4?dchild=1 amp;keywords=tattoo+green+soap amp;qid=1588206918 amp;sprefix=tattoo+green amp;sr=8-4#
love it! i love tattoos that are meant to sorta remind you that you wanna be happy :)))) that's what my lil paper plane does for me

listen you deleted your last post asking which pen ink to use. also, i understand feeling like shit and not caring if you harm yourself or not, but clearly you're worried about an infection. either use the pen ink and actually don't care if you mess up your skin or do it properly. this is just a cry for attention and you're perpetuating really unhealthy practices. snp can be a really good form of coping and therapy so i highly suggest you get in contact with a mental health specialist and discuss it with her. unless you're not worried, in which case save others from thinking this is an okay thing to post on here. mods please take this one down. tldr; based on your attitude it doesn't matter if it's infected or not right?

okay. i feel for you. just so you know, there's some pretty cheap ink available on amazon. sometimes if you look in craft stores, they'll have non-toxic india ink. as for the infection, see if there's any heat on the tattoo. if there is, it's very likely infected. first and foremost, best thing is to see a doctor. but i understand if you're not old enough to do this yourself. put a thin layer of antibacterial/antibiotic ointment on it 2-3 times a day but don't suffocate it. if it gets inflamed and pus starts forming, you don't have a choice. go to the doctor. in the future, try not approach a situation like this with the cynicism you did. more than anything, see a therapist. take a look at r/selfharm and try to find some solace. negligent self harm is still self harm. take care
second, third, and fourth all that ^^
appreciate this cause i re-drew it so many times #128517;thank u!

here's my take: professional tattoo transfer paper makes a huge difference when you want the exact image, bold and visible. if you wanna do some simple designs to start off before you get transfer paper or if your waiting for it in the mail, there's some pretty easy diy ways. personally, i started off by drawing directly onto my skin using a fine sharpie, or by using the following method. 1) draw design in pencil, making sure to get a substantial amount of graphite down (don't tear the paper) 2) go over the graphite with a bic ballpoint pen, again get as much ink down as you can. 3) apply transfer gel (or a non-toxic unscented deodorant) to skin and let air dry for ~30 seconds 4) press design onto skin ink side down and hold for ~15 seconds. this won't get perfect transfers, so i'd only recommend this for hand drawn tattoos. some tips: make sure you still clean the area beforehand, but keep in mind that this stencil wipes off very easily. you may want to make cuts in the piece of paper you use so the design can wrap flush against the skin. again, this will only really work for simple, small designs anyone correct me if i got smth wrong

so don't judge the source material but i learned how to do the diy technique from a guy on youtube called "the AfterPrisonShow" wouldn't recommend any of his other tattoo practices, but he does a good instructional on how to do the stencil.

WRITING.TITLE: Just a friendly reminder that tattoos shouldn't hurt too much and to be careful of depth #128077;

WRITING.TEXT: it's fake skin btw don't be alarmed lol

WRITING.TITLE: fake skin and smudging
WRITING.TEXT: i noticed some other people were having the same smudging problem i've been having with fake skin. even with putting vaseline beforehand, i still had some smudging. well i'm sure other people have already discovered this, but i just found that if you use a dry paper towel with a little bit of vaseline and rub out the smudges, it works pretty well. just thought i'd put this out there #128077;

if you're gonna nit-pick, fine. notice i used the terms "too much" meaning it is relative. no false information here, just subjective. also it's generally accepted that stick and pokes shouldn't cause substantial pain considering you're not supposed to break the second layer. and again, subjective. and logically speaking, pain that can't be tolerated is your body saying you shouldn't be doing something especially when it's one singular poke. have a nice day, officer
funny cause i was literally about to point out that you're essentially fighting against the advice that it's better to go too shallow than too deep... good luck with that #128514;god bless
sorry for all the danger i put new artists in by telling them to start shallow and gauge the depth #128514;

oh also nice try on the satanic imagery jab, but you really should've opened up the whole post... not a single satanic image on my body #128563; better luck next time #129335; #127997; #8205; #9794; #65039;

WRITING.TITLE: Advice on hard to reach spot
WRITING.TEXT: i wanna tattoo my upper arm (sort of outer shoulder) and i feel like i could stretch the skin with a combination of my knees, kt tape, and my poking hand, but i'm still weary. anyone have experience poking this area?
did you use isopropyl alcohol on the area?

sounds like you dried out your skin pretty bad. paired with the adhesive from the bandage, you probably just have some mild irritation. never use just rubbing alcohol on a tattoo. green soap has some, but in a much lower percentage. same thing happened to me on my leg.
if there isn't too much heat coming from it, you're probably okay. just keep an eye out for swelling, heat, and pus.

stretch skin, 45 degree angle, i use a movement that sort of "drags the needle". it's hard to explain, but essentially, i try my best to overlap pokes. imagine the dot you're creating, and try to put the next dot overlapping like a venn diagram. also, use a stencil. even if it's just pen on skin, you can see where your pokes need to go, even with the skin stretched.

haha no worries! i was pretty freaked out too but ever since then, i've used tegaderm and some gauze to cover with antibacterial ointment for about an hour, then from then on just leave it open to the air and gently wash once a day. with all the poking, wiping, and general abrasive-ness, the adhesives can really irritate your skin, even if you've never had a problem with them before. #128077;

WRITING.TITLE: Help some people out!
WRITING.TEXT: We got at least 100 people online in this sub at any given time: give some people some advice! too many unanswered questions in the new posts. i know it's possible to dig through the sub and online, but personal experiences can help a lot. and hey, it's quarantine, so what else are you doing #129335; #127997; #8205; #9794; #65039;.

WRITING.TEXT: we still talk and care about each other very much, but she can't be with me for a lot of reasons. if it feels wrong to be out looking, what does that mean? i don't mean i feel like im doing something wrong, but more that it's something that doesn't really satisfy me if that makes sense. what do i do?

yeah i agree. we need to weed out the people who are just like "hey how do i do this super dangerous thing safely? also i will not listen to anything you say if you say the super dangerous thing is super dangerous and i shouldn't do it :)"

looks great! instantly recognizable. i can't advocate graphite ink though... i used a pretty widely used recipe before and it fell out all at once when it was healing. i'd go for india ink over anything "homemade"

i was thinking of using another needle to spread them apart, and from there i can grab the two unused needles with anything really and bend them back

WRITING.TITLE: Rebound
WRITING.TEXT: So basically my gf (18f) broke up with me (19m) after 3 years. i still love her very much, but i struggle with anxiety and depression and i have a tendency to try to protect myself by rushing into new things. i'm not gonna meet up with anyone given quarantine, but i downloaded a couple of apps and started talking to a few people. and i'm tempted to make plans with other girls in my life. but i know i don't really want any of those things. i'm not really sure what i'm asking. i feel like there's a really slim chance that we would get back together, but i kind of want to bet on those odds. i know i shouldn't "wait" but i also don't want to cave into my defensive mechanisms and mess things up. more of a rant, but any advice is welcome.
thought i was having deja vu https://www.reddit.com/r/stickandpoketattoo/comments/ghbjnk/is_it_infected_am_i_having_an_allergic_reaction/?utm_source=share amp;utm_medium=ios_app amp;utm_name=iossmf
-s. beets. battlestar galactica.

WRITING.TITLE: this spot hurt like a mother. 9rl, 9rs, 15m. any advice for packing in blacks? i want this to eventually be solid black

WRITING.TEXT: looks sick! advice for sources on baybayin? #127477; #127469;
i like how it looked for the past 6 years and it's cool that it's "grown" now
kudos on keeping the style consistent up to now too!

personally, depending on what sizes you have available, i'd do all of this in liner needles. get the biggest liner you have for the majority of the tattoo (biggest one i have is 9rl) and use a 3-5 rl for the finer areas and borders

you could, but i personally regret trying to do my last tattoo (last post) with a 15 round magnum instead of just a liner. it fills it up well, but be ready to have a lot of "spread out" pain. personally i wasn't able to get my tattoo as dark as i'd like on the first session because the entire area was getting to sensitive. good to note that this was on my inner bicep though, so it's a pretty sensitive area as is. i'd say you'll eventually fill it in either way, but liner would be more concentrated, but less passes, and a mag would be more spread out, but more passes. of course a 9rs would also be good, but i find that i get frustrated with how little in they deposit.
this is the way
grip the same thumb to stretch the skin. when i was doing it, i even had a few objects to grip so the skin stretches in the right way

i can sympathize with what you're dealing with. i can't tell you this is what's happening in your relationship, but here's what i learned after having a very open and honest conversations with my girlfriend at the time. you have to consider (and accept) the possibility that her libido is just much lower than yours. i used to complain to my gf that i didn't feel she was intimate enough when we make out, so her wanting to do exactly what i asked, would do exactly what you describe (light touching, then getting up). at first this bugged me. but then she explained that she is attracted to me in that way, but sometimes she just doesn't feel like "initiating that kind of night" which is absolutely okay. as for why she lets you go down on her, well two reasons. 1) it feels good 2) she's assuming that you enjoy doing it so why wouldn't she turn it down? something really important i learned in that relationship is that yes, once you start rubbing and pulling clothes off, she gets horny. but before that, she might not be. and if she isn't horny, why would she try to initiate by going down on you. another important thing: whether or not you've had sex, there's also the chance that she doesn't want to start something that will end in sex because she doesn't want to right then. try not to take any of this personally. i know it's hard. but in those moments try to take a step back and look at the bigger picture. i know i wish i had.

yessir, that's the idea

also not a tattoo artist, but i've only worn gloves for tattooing other people. way i see it is that if i cut my nails and thoroughly wash my hands beforehand, i'm in the clear. i don't agree with the other comment though since you sweat everywhere. it shouldn't be a problem considering people get tattoos on their armpits. i think it's definitely important to be cautious, but (and again not a tattoo artist) a tattoo has basically the same risk of infection as any other wound. from what i've read, the gloves are mainly to prevent cross contamination of bacteria and blood between the artist and the client. so when i do my tats on myself, no gloves. especially in these times, it also seems a bit selfish to buy unnecessary medical equipment for cosmetic uses.

but this proves my point exactly... you're covered in bacteria. one way or another bacteria will eventually reach the tattoo. idk i've done all my tattoos glove free and haven't had any problems. also, surgery is a bit deeper than a tattoo so i imagine the risk of infection increases drastically. again, not a doctor or tattoo artist, but personally, i've had much deeper wounds with much larger risks of infection that don't get infected using basic sanitary practices. i think it's a bit overkill to try and keep everything absolutely sterile; bacteria falls off your skin from your forehead, a cough could send bacteria into your area, you might momentarily touch an un-sterile part of your body while trying to stretch skin, etc. my opinion is that by the end of the tattoo, your gloves will be just as "dirty" as a hand washed with anti bacterial soap. if it makes you feel better, wear gloves, but they aren't immune to the risk of taking on bacteria.

my bad lol i didn't know it was that deep for you. you're absolutely right. best sanitary practice is ALWAYS advised. hopefully you know i agree with you there. so the following is not advice, simply information with which one can use at their own risk on their own body: tattooing has been around forever; people used to use "unsanitary" tools, from thorns as needles, and tree sap as ink. and yes, these are still practices in many parts of the world. people get tattoos in the middle of the jungle and they don't get infected. yeah it's a matter of chance, but every time you get a tattoo, you risk infection no matter how by-the-books you are. yes doing things like using professional needles, professional ink, and gloves will lower that risk, but the risk still exists. if you're the kind of person who wants to absolutely lower your chances of infection, go the whole 9 (which i would recommend for new tattooers since you don't know how your body will react). personally, i know my body can handle bacteria very well as i've gotten multiple cuts and scrapes that were nowhere near sanitized. TLDR: wearing gloves is like wearing a seatbelt. yeah it's pretty stupid not to wear one but you likely won't die. in that one in a hundred, yeah it might make a difference, but you take the risk knowing your capabilities and experiences. PS: most of this is for anyone else reading this, but to you: don't take reddit comments too serious my guy. idek you. best of luck #128077;

after deliberation with the lovely redditor below, the answer to your question of "is it 100% necessary" is no, it's not. none of the safety practices are necessary, but they are highly recommended if you want to avoid infection. it's not necessary that you cook your food, but it'll decrease your chance of getting sick drastically. now for the "wrong" opinion (lol) in the list of precautions necessary for stick and poke on yourself, i'd say gloves rank pretty low. the only reason i say this is because i personally think it would be ridiculous to hold back from doing a tattoo because i didn't have gloves. personally, that's a very small risk im willing to take.

don't listen to this ^ professional tattoo artists recommend aquaphor. just not too much

this is just straight up wrong. you're talking about vaseline. aquaphor is a healing ointment. to OP, you can listen to this guy, or do a quick google search and see its recommended by a lot of artists.
im not sure what that is, but if i had to guess, it looks like an ingrown hair. just give it a couple of days to see if it goes away
https://www.healthline.com/health/body-modification/aquaphor-tattoo#benefits please do research before making definite statements.

okay i can't tell if you're serious. ONE of aquaphors ingredients is petroleum jelly (which is what vaseline is btw). you keep doing you homie but you're just wrong #128514; #128514; #128514; good luck buddy and try to do some reading okay?

to anyone else reading this, this guy doesn't have a grip on how medicine works. aquaphor has three main ingredients: petroleum jelly (which protects the skin), lanolin, and glycerin. the two other ingredients help to pull moisture from the air into the skin. i'm not really sure what kind of backwards scientific method this guy is using for his research, but looking up one ingredient of a product just makes no sense... y'all stay safe out there and don't listen to dudes like this #128514; #129313;

honestly, what helped me the most is accepting that i'm not a tattoo artist, so with each tattoo, i try my best, but i know that the value goes beyond just how it looks. i'm barely a good drawer, so my first tattoo looks terrible (peep the cactus in my history) but i wouldn't want it removed. i'd say be okay with messing up (by putting it in a hidden/personal spot). also start small. you can try using fruits/fake skin as practice, but in my experience, there's a huge difference in technique. start with a small line on your foot, see how that feels/looks, and adjust your technique accordingly.
just an idea, but on first glance i saw a bottle. add a couple more "fractures" and you could turn it into a suspended broken bottle

fuck these haters. the logic is so skewed. if it's something offensive to you, don't tattoo it on you. if i tattooed a skull on my arm, you wouldn't bat an eye. now if i told you the meaning of it is to symbolize the the death of a certain race, then it's problematic. intention matters. these people outright signing it off as a racist symbol is exactly why it still has the negative connotations. example: during the crusades, the cross became a symbol of destruction and evil for many people. yet the positive connotation has dominated because people chose to associate it with the good.

if you want to tattoo again, i use my upper thigh and ankle as practice spots since they're less visible. and if i really mess something up, i kind of just accept that that's one of my many mistakes. personally, the way i see it is that if i got a scrape or a cut, i really don't care enough to try and prevent scarring (even on my face). so i'm not too concerned in general about permanent, visible mistakes. if you're more of the type of person who would try 10 different products to prevent a scar, i would practice on fruit and fake skin until you're comfortable with the level of risk (less time practicing = higher risk of messing up obviously, so you'll know when you're comfortable with the level of risk that your skill comes with) that last part is a but convoluted, but i hope you understand what i'm getting at
thanks! would love to see yours cause i kinda still want to do a color wheel once i have enough colors to mix and blend

WRITING.TEXT: read the title and thought you were being cocky lol. i've found that the same think happens to me with other people too. i've always chalked it up to being a lot more comfortable and informed when tattooing yourself. since you can "feel" the depth on yourself and if something hurts too much, you can go faster and deeper sooner. with other people i find myself going more shallow and paying more attention to their reaction. also possible that your friend just has different skin that takes ink less easily.
that's exactly what i'm scared of. it's helps to know that the person will communicate pain accurately so i try to emphasize that before

im gonna be honest... i'm a wrestler so we see a lot of skin infections over the years and the only things i've seen that looked exactly like this was a pretty nasty mrsa infection and a staph infection. go see a doctor. it may seem small, but infection can seriously fuck you up.
i think in this instance, neosporin was justified

that's a terrible reason. fake email, fake account, hell: even send it to a friend's address. put some effort into it before your parents find out by having to take you to the doctor for your new skin infection

WRITING.TITLE: How to properly clean sewing needles and india ink!
WRITING.TEXT: you can't. stop using sewing needles. india ink isn't sterile. why would you even think there's a "proper" way to clean this? go buy some tattoo needles. "my parents will find out" is a terrible excuse. make a fake amazon account. send it to a drop box. stand guard at the door to grab the package before they see. you can get 60 needles and .5 oz of ink for total $20. if you can't afford that, then you definitely can't afford the potential medical bills. and if you still want to use sewing needles, stop asking dumbass questions like "hOw Do I mAkE tHe SeWiNg NeEdLe HuRt LeSs???
yes, i think this valid cause i've been there too, but continuing once you know all the dangers and other choices, i think it's ridiculous at this point

here's something actually helpful [needles](https://www.amazon.com/Tattoo-Needles-Set-Disposable-Assorted/dp/B07XKYS4YJ/ref=mp_s_a_1_3?dchild=1 amp;keywords=tattoo+needles amp;qid=1593292095 amp;sr=8-3) [ink](https://www.amazon.com/Millennium-Moms-Millenium-Milennium-Pigment/dp/B004UALTUG/ref=mp_s_a_1_6?dchild=1 amp;keywords=tattoo+ink amp;qid=1593292155 amp;sr=8-6)

see, i completely understand that. i've seen some good looking jail tats, but i think the key think you said is doing what you can with what you have. i won't ridicule someone for getting a tattoo with a staple or a pen spring if it's in jail or smth, but nowadays, all it takes is patience of waiting for the package to come in or to save up money to buy supplies. i just feel like if you can't have the patience to wait to get real supplies when it's readily available, you shouldn't be tattooing yourself because you need to be somewhat calculated in what you're doing.
agreed. i understand not caring about the consequences sometimes and just needing that tattoo, but at the same time, if you want to keep tattooing, you have to take caution at some point.
did you mix these?
it looks really good! been thinking of doing some gradients... any tips?
thank you! did you mark your transitions beforehand? or if you were to do a thicker design, would you draw a line where the colors would start to turn?
why don't you like amazon?

[here](https://www.reddit.com/r/sticknpokes/comments/hgzseb/how_to_properly_clean_sewing_needles_and_india_ink/fw7c1qo/?utm_source=share amp;utm_medium=ios_app amp;utm_name=iossmf) buy everything else at a pharmacy (vaseline, aftercare lotion, gloves, rubbing alcohol, witch hazel, etc.)

amazon's a marketplace so it's really about the different sellers.. try to discern which products have actual reviews and legit looking product pages. otherwise, just google search those companies i guess.

yeah that's fair, i'd try to find an official dynamic or kuro sumi website; those are pretty popular. oh and i just remembered that [stickandpoketattookit.com](https://stickandpoketattookit.com/how-to-stick-and-poke/) sells ink sets that are in .5 oz bottles. i've personally used them and they work alright. a tad overpriced, but shipping is decently quick and the ink took to my skin pretty well
how did you do the ink rubbing?
i get that, i've looked it up before and i'd never try myself but i was wondering if rubbing ink on a fresh tattoo (like right after it's done) would help pack any ink
that's true. i've just been using leftover ink anyway. the tats look sick btw. even though the triangle isn't perfect, the method makes it sick

i haven't done too much with color, but i wouldn't overlap anything cause it will mix the two colors (green will turn lime green, orange will turn a lighter orange) i would try to color each separately as best you can
so you're reusing that needle?
i agree, but this totally looks fixable with the next touch up
im not so sure about this... just technically speaking, we depend on context for color so if you actually put the ink in, it'll affect the color
